image.altText: People in high-vis gear stand in a line and walk through long grass in scrubland.

items.synopsis: Fourteen-year-old Shyanne-Lee Tatnell has not been seen or heard from since April 30. Now community members are getting involved in the search to find her.

title.children: Family of missing 14yo says they're 'absolutely broken' as search goes into 10th day

image.altText: Horses trek through dirt.

items.synopsis: Right to Information documents show a complaint about "race fixing" against Tasmania's leading harness racing stable was received by the Office of Racing Integrity in 2016, seven years before an extensive ABC investigation.

title.children: Racing integrity office had complaint of alleged 'race fixing' against Ben Yole dating back to 2016

image.altText: Raging flames in a bushfire setting.

items.synopsis: Months of smoke aerosols profusely pumping into the atmosphere during the 2019–2020 bushfires likely triggered a chain reaction that influenced the onset and intensity of the La Niña events, a US study has found.

title.children: Black Summer bushfires may have helped trigger rare triple-dip La Niña

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Warren Mundine speak at a meeting. Mr Mundine has his arm out gesturing.

items.synopsis: The two campaigns pushing for a No vote to the forthcoming Voice to Parliament referendum merge, in a move that aims to unify their message and strengthen their campaign.

title.children: Key 'No' Voice camps merge to strengthen referendum campaign

image.altText: man sitting next to bride

items.synopsis: A Sydney "self-taught trader" charged with allegedly defrauding "mum and dad-type" investors of more than $24 million has been refused bail.

title.children: Bail refused for man charged who allegedly gambled 'away almost $25 million' in investor funds

image.altText: A dark-haired woman looks at her young daughter, who's facing her in a swing

items.synopsis: Tasmanians are waiting years instead of days to access vital ear, nose and throat specialist appointments. The Department of Health is trying to find a solution.

title.children: Girl, 7, who 'can't eat properly' set for a six-year wait to get tonsils out

image.altText: The two men walk outside in winter coats, Drumgold carrying paperwork.

items.synopsis: Shane Drumgold, the ACT Director of Public Prosecutions, tells an inquiry he was mistaken to believe federal politicians had interfered with a rape investigation.

title.children: Chief prosecutor says he was wrong to suspect political interference in Bruce Lehrmann case

image.altText: A man speaks in parliament wearing a suit with various politicians seated on the green benches behind him

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers used his budget speech this week to spruik the government's credentials and programs. But did he keep his facts straight?

title.children: We fact checked Jim Chalmers's budget night speech. Here's what we found

image.altText: Two men in suits walking under a tree with orange leaves in the courtyard of Parliament House.

items.synopsis: The federal government needs to keep young voters on side to get a second term in office, but this year's budget doesn't present a particularly compelling plan for under 30s, writes Claudia Long.

title.children: 'Band-aids on bullet holes': Why Labor snubs younger Australians at its peril

image.altText: A Sydney tram with emergency workers alongside

items.synopsis: Emergency services worked to free the 16-year-old, who had critical injuries, but she died at the scene.

title.children: Teenage girl dies after becoming trapped under light rail tram in Sydney CBD

image.altText: Headshot of WA Premier Mark McGowan speaking

items.synopsis: The WA budget is being announced, with the state expected to confirm a $4 billion surplus. Follow live as we unpack the details.

title.children: Mark McGowan's latest budget is set to confirm WA's place as the richest state in the nation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ABC reporter Daniel Mercer has an early scoop on what we can expect in this budget. Dan writes: The cash bonanza is once again tipped to fund big subsidies for WA electricity users, with households poised to receive an across-the-board rebate of $400 off their bills. This will be on top of the $350 of energy bill assistance to flow from the federal budget to vulnerable customers. Almost $5 billion worth of spending has already been announced. Here's the big ticket stuff: $2.3 billion for two new giant batteries in Collie and Kwinana A $511 million social housing package $420 million for an expansion of the state's mental health services expansion $368 million for new and expanded wind farms in the Mid West There's also tens of millions for new schools, various public hospital upgrades, social services and mineral exploration.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Households to get $400 electricity credit

children.content: ABC reporter
Daniel Mercer
has an early scoop on what we can expect in this budget.
Dan writes:
The cash bonanza is once again tipped to fund big subsidies for WA electricity users, with households poised to receive an across-the-board rebate of $400 off their bills.
This will be on top of the $350 of energy bill assistance to flow from the federal budget to vulnerable customers.

props.alt: cash lays on a kitchen table beside a cup of tea and a list of bills owing

children.content: Almost $5 billion worth of spending has already been announced. Here's the big ticket stuff:
$2.3 billion
for two new giant batteries in Collie and Kwinana
A
$511 million
social housing package
$420 million
for an expansion of the state's mental health services expansion
$368 million
for new and expanded wind farms in the Mid West
There's also tens of millions for new schools, various public hospital upgrades, social services and mineral exploration.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello and thanks for joining our live coverage of this year's state budget! Across the afternoon and into the evening, we'll be bringing you all of the key moments and reactions to a set of books that is expected to post another huge surplus, amid a cost-of-living crisis for many. The most important question we'll be seeking to answer is what this budget means for YOU. If you've got any questions or thoughts, use the blue Leave a Comment button above to send them in. We'd love to hear from you! At the moment, our ABC News reporters are locked in a room at Dumas House pouring over the details and will be set free to tell you all about it from 2:00pm WST.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to our live coverage of the 2023 WA budget

children.content: Hello and thanks for joining our live coverage of this year's state budget!

Across the afternoon and into the evening, we'll be bringing you all of the key moments and reactions to a set of books that is expected to post another huge surplus, amid a cost-of-living crisis for many.
The most important question we'll be seeking to answer is what this budget means for YOU.
If you've got any questions or thoughts, use the blue
Leave a Comment
button above to send them in. We'd love to hear from you!
At the moment, our ABC News reporters are locked in a room at Dumas House pouring over the details and will be set free to tell you all about it from 2:00pm WST.

image.altText: A woman wearing blue scrubs has her arm around an older woman wearing a pink cardigan as they walk across a lush green lawn.

items.synopsis: Older Australians are increasingly opting to receive care at home, rather than in residential aged care, a shift that the federal government projects will save billions of dollars.

title.children: Deep within the budget was a revelation: The way the government views aged care is changing

image.altText: a homemade missing poster with a picture of a woman printed on white paper and thumbtacked to a fence

items.synopsis: Police have suspended their search at an Ipswich dump for missing Toowong woman Lesley Trotter, whose body is believed to have been put in a wheelie bin outside her home last month.

title.children: Police suspend search of landfill site for missing woman Lesley Trotter's body

image.altText: A man in blue jeans, shirt, vest, beanie, stands leaning on a moss-covered tree in the forest.

items.synopsis: A collection preserving physical specimens from Tasmania's tallest forest grove of flowering plants will help ensure opportunity for future research of the ancient giants.

title.children: Yoav says these trees hold clues to our past, but a fire could destroy them. So he is saving them one leaf at a time

image.altText: A piece of land with the Australian flag and the Chinese flag next to each other with a big crack separating the two

items.synopsis: Australia's Trade Minister Don Farrell will hold a meeting with his Chinese counterpart in Beijing this week, with hopes it could signal the trade turmoil between China and Australia will soon be over.

title.children: Trade Minister Don Farrell to visit China in push to end trade bans on barley, meat and wine

image.altText: An LNG tanker

items.synopsis: Energy company Eni has quietly revived plans to develop a gas field in the Timor Sea which contains some of the most carbon-intensive gas in Australia, "far more than any other gas field that is being developed".

title.children: Italian company moves ahead with 'carbon bomb' gas field in Timor Sea

image.altText: Tamarama House "Lang Syne"is sold for undisclosed sum

items.synopsis: The bungalow was owned by late radio star Harry Griffiths and has been held by the family for over six decades.

title.children: Sydney oceanfront property sells for close to $45 million amid cost-of-living crunch

image.altText: A middle-aged woman looks at the camera, standing in front of a sandstone wall

items.synopsis: A group of people whose families profited from slavery is trying to make amends for past wrongs.

title.children: Laura is an 'heir of slavery'. Here's what she's doing to remedy her family's brutal legacy

image.altText: A moody atmospheric photo of festival-goers in a paddock.

items.synopsis: The teenager was able to escape and raise the alarm after the alleged attack at the Bunbury event. Police are appealing for witnesses to come forward.

title.children: Police hunt for man who allegedly sexually assaulted teenage girl at Groovin the Moo festival

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

items.synopsis: The Supreme Court trial of accused Greg Lynn will not begin until next year after his barrister raised "funding issues" at a court hearing.

title.children: Alleged High Country murder trial delay as accused Greg Lynn faces 'funding issues'

image.altText: A sign that says Calvary Hospital on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: Canberra's Catholic archdiocese says it's dismayed and disappointed by the ACT government's decision to take over the Catholic-owned Calvary Public Hospital.

title.children: Catholic church 'dismayed' by ACT government takeover of hospital, but medical group backs plan

image.altText: A family portrait of a mother, father, son and daughter in a field.

items.synopsis: A central Queensland mine operator has been cleared of breaching workplace health and safety laws over the death of a miner, despite a court ruling there was an "obvious" risk with faulty machinery.

title.children: Faulty brakes on mining equipment involved in worker death 'could have been detected pre incident', judge finds

image.altText: DUPLICATE vape

items.synopsis: A Brisbane convenience store has been caught with 45,000 vapes and ordered to pay $88,000 for possessing and selling vapes containing nicotine.

title.children: Principal tips off investigators about sale of vapes to school children, resulting in conviction

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: Local shares are trading lower after overnight news that US inflation is cooling but still too high. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX slips after mixed day on Wall Street as inflation cools

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The number of homes up for auction this week has increased 1.6 per cent, but it's still 40 per cent lower than a year ago. There are 1,751 homes expected to go under the hammer across the combined capitals, according to data from Corelogic. Melbourne is the busiest capital city for auctions, with 728 scheduled - 43.6% below the 1,291 auctions that were held a year ago. There are 654 homes scheduled to go under the hammer in Sydney this week, 30.9% below the 946 held this week last year. Capital city auction activity is expected to rise over the coming weeks, with around 1,950 homes currently scheduled for auction next week and roughly 1,900 auctions booked for the final week of May. Last week’s final combined capitals clearance rate of 69.9% was the highest recorded since late February 2022.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Auctions still 40 pc lower than last year

children.content: The number of homes up for auction this week has increased 1.6 per cent, but it's still 40 per cent lower than a year ago.
There are 1,751 homes expected to go under the hammer across the combined capitals, according to data from Corelogic.
Melbourne is the busiest capital city for auctions, with 728 scheduled -
43.6% below the 1,291 auctions that were held a year ago.
There are 654 homes scheduled to go under the hammer in Sydney this week, 30.9% below the 946 held this week last year.
Capital city auction activity is expected to rise over the coming weeks, with around 1,950 homes currently scheduled for auction next week and roughly 1,900 auctions booked for the final week of May.
Last week’s final combined capitals clearance rate of 69.9% was the highest recorded since late February 2022.
Capital city auction statistics
(Corelogic)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chinese coal imports are fading as local production ramps up. China’s coal imports dipped slightly from March to April, with the year-on-year comparison slowing from 152% in March to 73% in April. "The rise in imports has been accompanied by an increase in China’s domestic coal output. Typically, a synchronous increase in both coal production and imports indicates rising coal demand in China," CBA Commodities analyst Vivek Dhar notes. "Industrial output data from last quarter does confirm this narrative. China’s crude steel output has increased ~6%/yr in Q1 2023, supporting the case for higher coking coal output and imports," henotes. "Thermal power output (i.e. mostly coal) has also lifted ~2%/yr in the same time period, largely carried by a ~9%/yr increase in thermal power output in March." Mr Dhar says the increase in China’s coal imports likely indicates some opportunistic buying too. "The sharp fall in international thermal coal prices relative to local prices has made it more attractive to purchase imports for the better part of this year. " China’s thermal coal imports from Australia has been a key beneficiary of this price differential following the end of China’s unofficial ban on Australian coal, Mr Dhar notes. "With the price differential now favouring local coal in the last few weeks, it’s likely that China’s coal imports from Australia will likely moderate. Alongside ongoing evidence of fading industrial demand, we expect China’s total coal imports will start sliding too," Mr Dhar notes. IRON ORE IMPORTS FELL IN APRIL China’s iron ore imports also dropped last month, down 10%. Like coal, China’s iron ore imports have eased in year‑on‑year terms from March to April. "We think it will be challenging for China’s steel output and iron ore imports to keep expanding in coming months given China’s steel mill margins have remained in negative territory since late March. China’s gas imports, which includes both pipeline and LNG, rose by 1% in the month to April and 11% in the year to April.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China’s coal and iron ore import growth slow

children.content: Chinese coal imports are fading as local production ramps up.
China’s coal imports dipped slightly from March to April, with the year-on-year comparison slowing from 152% in March to 73% in April.
"The rise in imports has been accompanied by an increase
in China’s domestic coal output.
Typically, a synchronous increase in both coal production and imports indicates rising coal demand in China,"
CBA Commodities analyst Vivek Dhar notes.

"Industrial output data from last quarter does confirm this narrative. China’s crude steel output has increased ~6%/yr in Q1 2023, supporting the case for higher coking coal output and imports," henotes.
"Thermal power output (i.e. mostly coal) has also lifted ~2%/yr in the same time period, largely carried by a ~9%/yr increase in thermal power output in March."
Mr Dhar says the increase in China’s coal imports likely indicates some opportunistic buying too.
"The sharp fall in international thermal coal prices relative to local prices has made it more attractive to purchase imports for the better part of this year. "
China’s thermal coal imports from Australia has been a key beneficiary of this price differential following the end of China’s unofficial ban on Australian coal, Mr Dhar notes.

"With the price differential now favouring local coal in the last few weeks, it’s likely that China’s coal imports from Australia will likely moderate. Alongside ongoing evidence of fading industrial demand, we expect China’s total coal imports will start sliding too," Mr Dhar notes.
IRON ORE IMPORTS FELL IN APRIL
China’s iron ore imports also dropped last month, down 10%.
Like coal, China’s iron ore imports have eased in year‑on‑year terms from March to April.

"We think it will be challenging for China’s steel output and iron ore imports to keep expanding in coming months given China’s steel mill margins have remained in negative territory since late March.
China’s gas imports, which includes both pipeline and LNG, rose by 1% in the month to April and 11% in the year to April.

image.altText: An old image of Heather Winchester sitting on the couch holding her baby grandson.

items.synopsis: The Newcastle doctor has told an inquest that the Jehovah's Witness patient was lucid and clear while refusing a potentially life-saving blood transfusion.

title.children: Jehovah's Witness woman preferred to die than accept blood transfusion, distressed doctor tells inquest

image.altText: Man smiling with a farm field in the background

items.synopsis: Three Supreme Court justices handed down their judgement today, rejecting Midfield Meat International's appeal bid and finding none of the grounds of appeal had "any real prospect of success".

title.children: Meat processor's bid to appeal conviction and $400k fine over worker death fails

image.altText: Man in diving gear touching the mouth of a large whale shark underwater.

items.synopsis: Making a natural history documentary is a test of patience and endurance, and Tim Winton had finally run out of both. He was trying to capture the wild beauty of his beloved Ningaloo Reef but Mother Nature wouldn't play ball.

title.children: Tim Winton picked parasites off whale shark's mouth, but that's not what 'terrified' him

image.altText: Jess and Jackie Morecroft stand in the driveway of their home.

items.synopsis: After a five-year court battle, the Morecrofts lost their Gold Coast family home. Now they're facing legal costs that could financially ruin them.

title.children: Couple told they never owned house they paid for 'at wits' end' over order to pay legal costs

image.altText: Prince Harry with a beard and furrowed brow wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: A British tabloid newspaper apologises to Prince Harry for unlawfully seeking information about him at the start of the royal's lawsuit against its publisher over alleged phone hacking, in which he is due to give evidence himself.

title.children: 'Blatantly unlawful': British tabloid apologises to Prince Harry

image.altText: Photo of an industrial storage tank with a no smoking sign in front.

items.synopsis: Economists and energy experts say the government is short-changing Australians with planned changes to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax that will only raise an additional $2.4 billion over five years.

title.children: Smokers will see a bigger tax increase than multinational gas producers. Is it fair?

image.altText: A view from a helicopter shows charred grounds and a large plume of smoke coming from a forested area.

items.synopsis: The death toll has risen to 21 in a series of fires raging in Russia's Urals region, some resulting from suspected arson, while medical officials warn the tally is likely to increase, Russian state news agency TASS reports.

title.children: Death toll from wildfires in Russia's Urals hits 21, authorities suspect arson

image.altText: A white labradoodle dog stands proudly next to his certificate

items.synopsis: A rural teacher says the effort that has gone into training her labradoodle to be a therapy dog is worth it as soon as she sees how students and staff interact with him.

title.children: When Alby the labradoodle starts his day as a school therapy dog, he knows he's got a 'job to do'
